Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Beyond Stability: Performance, Efficiency and Disturbance Management for Smart Infrastructure Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Infrastructure networks are the foundation of the modern world. Their continued reliable and efficient function without exhausting finite natural resources is critical to the security, continued growth and technological advancement of the United States. Currently these systems are in a state of rapid flux due to a collision of trends such as growing populations, expanding integration of information technology, and increasing motivation to adopt sustainable practices. These trends beget both exciting potential benefits and dangerous challenges. Added sensing, communication, and computational capabilities hold the promise of increased reliability, efficiency and sustainability from "smart" infrastructure systems. At the same time, new technologies such as renewable energy resources in power systems, autonomous vehicles, and software defined communication networks, are testing the limits of current operational and market policies. The rapidly changing suite of system components can cause new, unforeseen interactions that can lead to instability, performance deterioration, or catastrophic failures. Achieving the full benefits of these systems will require a shift from the existing focus on approaches that analyze each aspect of interest in isolation, to a more holistic view that encompasses all of the relevant factors such as stability, robustness, performance and efficiency, and takes into account the presence of human participants.

This project provides a research roadmap to construct analysis, design and control tools that ensure the seamless integration of computational algorithms, physical components and human interactions in next generation infrastructure systems. Although there has been a great deal of research on stability questions in large scale distributed systems, there has been little effort directed toward questions of performance, robustness and efficiency in these systems, especially those with heterogeneous components and human participants. This research employs coupled oscillator systems as a common modeling framework to (i) characterize stability and performance of infrastructure systems, and (ii) develop distributed controllers that guarantee performance, efficiency and robustness by isolating disturbances and optimizing performance objectives. Practical solutions require that the theory be tightly integrated with the economic mechanisms necessary to incentivize users to enhance system stability, efficiency and reliability; therefore the work will also include the design of economic controls. In order to ground the mathematical foundations, theory and algorithms described above, the results will be applied to three target infrastructure networks where coupled oscillator models have played a foundational role in design and control: power, communication, and transportation systems. This approach allows the development of cross-cutting, fundamental principles that can be applied across problem specific boundaries and ensures that the research makes an impact on these specific infrastructure networks. This project will also incorporate concepts into existing undergraduate and graduate courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The continued reliable and efficient function of modern infrastructure systems without exhaustingfinite natural resources is critical to the security, continued growth and technological advancement of theUnited States. The increasing integration of sensing and communication, new technologies and the desireto adopt sustainable practices is fundamentally changing the make-up of these systems and the way com-ponents interact with one another. Although these advanced technologies provide exciting opportunitiesto increase efficiency, reliability and reduce the overall carbon footprint of next generation infrastructure,interactions between the rapidly changing suite of system components can also lead to new, unforeseeninstabilities, performance deterioration, or catastrophic failures. Achieving the full benefits of these sys-tems thus requires a holistic view that encompasses all of the relevant factors such as stability, robustness,performance and efficiency, and takes into account the presence of human participants. This project tooka multidisciplinary approach to design the required core mathematical foundations, theory, algorithmsand tools to evaluate and improve efficiency, performance, and disturbance management of infrastructurenetworks. Design of economic controls to incentivize users to enhance system stability, efficiency andreliability was tightly integrated with the research to ensure that the theory could be adapted in prac-tice. The core theory and mathematical tools were demonstrated on three target infrastructure systems:power systems, communication networks and transportation networks.

Intellectual Merits The project involved four main research thrusts. The first research thrust wasconcerned with developing systematic tools to quantify system performance in terms of how efficientlya system maintains a desired state in the presence of disturbances or measurement error. One majoroutcome of this work is a new framework for evaluating performance in models of vehicle and powernetworks with both directed and symmetric communication structures. The tools have been leveraged toevaluate common criteria such as Nadir, RoCoF used to evaluate frequency issues in power systems andvoltage deviations in microgrids with heterogeneous components. Performance aware control techniques(thrust 2) leveraged these ideas in next generation decentralized dynamic control designs that move awayfrom the preventative approaches common in traditional power grid control towards a reactive approachthat uses new types of grid resources more efficiently to increase resiliency without sacrificing reliability.The performance analysis framework that allows generalized directed communication between systemcomponents was leveraged to analyze the effect of communication and network structure on the abilityto maintain coordinated function, which has implications for the sensing and interconnection require-ments for ensuring desired behaviors. In the final research thrust we developed layered architecturesfor infrastructure networks that integrate economic and engineered control, and have the potential torevolutionize how power system markets are operated. In particular, to provide a means to maintainefficiency and reliability as the composition of the grid resources changes requiring tighter coupling offast time scale engineering and slower time scale economic control. Additional economic analysis focusedon the integration of new resources such as energy storage and distributed energy resources (modeled asstrategic generation and loads) into two stage electricity markets.

Broader Impacts This project developed a framework to systematically evaluate performance andleveraged the insights gained in the design of both engineering and economic control tools to improveefficiency, disturbance mitigation and reliability in three critical infrastructure systems: power , commu-nication and transportation networks. At JHU the project supported 1 MS student, 3 PhD students and1 postdoctoral scholar. These junior researchers benefited from the multi-institution team that broughtapplication specific expertise that enabled the theory developed to be relevant to the three target in-frastructure networks. One undergraduate researcher won several JHU undergraduate research awardsbased on her preliminary results, e.g. Huggins ECE Fellowship 2018, the Muly Family UndergraduateResearch Award, and the Provosts Undergraduate Research Award.The JHU portion of the project led to 11 journal (9 published, 1 accepted and 1 in revision) articles,30 conference proceedings (2 are submitted), 1 MS research essay and a PhD thesis.

The research has been shared with the scientific community through conferences, workshops, and seminars at nationallaboratories and universities. The project has included a number of different educational componentsincluding yearly lectures at a JHU STEM summer program (Engineering Innovation) for high school stu-dents from around the country, lectures at local Baltimore high schools and in Freshmen and Sophomorelevel classes at JHU. The PI also participated in the inaugural US version of Pint of Science in orderto explain wind energy and how wind farms can be controlled to provide power grid support to a broadaudience. This event at a local Baltimore bar explained power systems to the community and allowedfor interaction and engagement.
